intro.para: Recall: a linear function L\from \RNr[n] \to \RNr[n] is invertible if its transformation effect can be reversed. Now let V and W are subvector spaces of \RNr[k]. Nicely enough, a linear function L\from V\to W is invertible exactly when there exists a linear map M\from W\to V such that L and M reverse each other's transformation effect.

Next we look for criteria to identify invertible linear maps. In this section we show: L is invertible if and only if the matrix representing L with respect to any choice of ordered bases of V and W is invertible. We will develop additional criteria in subsequent sections.

Invertible linear transformation
Definition of the concept: A linear map L\from V\to W of subvector spaces of \RNr[k] is invertible, if there exists a linear map M\from W\to V such that
M\Comp L = \Id[V] \quad\text{and}\quad L\Comp M = \Id[W]
In this case we call M the inverse of L and write M=L^{-1}.
